titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. IV:30. Wednesday. Wrote a Letter to J. L. Sullivan in answer to that received from him; and one or two others. Received at the Office a Letter from the President of the United States— Called upon Mr Crawford, at the Treasury, to ask him for copies of his circular to the Collectors of the Customs on the execution of the Navigation Act of the last Session of Congress, which goes into Operation this day. Sent one of them to Mr Bagot. A Roman Catholic Clergyman, a Jesuit, named Coleman, with a Mr Divoff and another came and left a Letter and a small parcel to be forwarded to Russia. They told me that my old friend the General of the Jesuits Brzozowski was at Polotzk—not permitted either to return to St. Petersburg or to go out of Russia— But he hoped soon to obtain leave to go to Italy. Having less interruption this day than usual I employed much of the morning in reading despatches from J. A. Smith to the Department. R. Forrest, mentioned to me a house of Captain Davidson, for sale; and after dinner I took a walk to look at it. In the Evening I began to draw up the Instructions for R. Rush. Reflected upon a general principle for drafting Instructions to Ministers going abroad— First idea; reference to the Treaties between the two Countries—began upon that— To consult Rush himself.— Some particulars of instructions should be circular—what are they?

2. IV: Continued drafting instructions for Rush. The Subject opens upon me as I proceed— I shall be at no loss for want of matter. wrote to Delaplaine, and to Dr Waterhouse— Received a Letter from him and his late pamphlet, on the Dysentery. Commodore Charles Morris was at the Office, just returned from a Cruize in the Congress Frigate to the West Indies and on the Spanish Main. He took out an agent named Tyler, employed by the Government upon some claims of American Citizens on the Black Governments of Christophe and Pethion in St. Domingo. King Henry of Hayti refused to receive the Agent, as not knowing any such person as Christophe or any such place as Cape François— My Tyler died on the passage home. Morris has collected some information about the state of affairs between Morillo’s Spanish forces and the South American insurgents in Caraccas— Rush was also at the Office— I told him I believed he must do as Sully did when he was sent to England by Henry the fourth of France, and draw up his own Instructions. At all events I asked him to make a minute of all the subjects upon which he wished for Instructions, which he promised. The Accounts of Salaries for the Department, for the quarter just expired were made up, and approved by me. Rush refuses to receive the Salary of Secretary of State, from the day of my landing at New-York— I had urged that he should receive it until the day that I was sworn into Office, for which there was a Precedent in the case of Mr L. Lincoln, who as Attorney General in 1801 discharged the duties and received the Salary of Secretary of State until the arrival of Mr Madison, who was appointed to that Office— Rush positively declined, and the accounts make the Salary payable to me from the 6th. of August— I received a Letter from the President. G. Boyd came to me about the settlement of the Account for the books purchased by me for the War Department, and also of an account of his own at the State Department, for charges upon his Mission to Ghent in 1814. Mr Rush and Pleasonton he says make difficulties about one charge. He refers to a verbal promise from Mr Monroe which that Gentleman does not recollect— I cannot settle the question— We had fires at the Office yesterday and this day— Mrs Hellen, and D. P. Cook dined with us at Frye’s— The Boyd’s and Smith’s were invited and did not come— At eight in the Evening I retired to bed.

3. IV: I had visits this morning from Mr Levett Harris, Mr Nourse the Register of the Treasury, and Mr Correa de Serra, the Portuguese Minister— Harris had just returned from visits to Mr Jefferson, Mr Madison, and President Monroe, and Correa was going to pay them. Correa says he calls them the Presidential Trinity, and that last year he called them the past, the present and the future. Harris came among other things for the settlement of his accounts in which there are some extraordinary charges. Among the rest 1332 dollars for the expences of his nephew in bringing my despatches containing the Emperor Alexander’s offer of Mediation. I told Harris there had never been any idea that there was to be any expence for his nephew’s bringing the despatches, which he fully admitted; but he said it had cost him as much as he had charged. His nephew was shipwrecked on the Coast of Finland; then was obliged to go to Gothenburg by Land, and to England in the Packet. Thence to Bermuda likewise in a Packet, and thence at equal expence to this Country. He had therefore made the charge, but would leave it entirely to my determination. His account was approved with the exception of that charge which is
left for the President’s determination— I wrote to the President, and to David Holmes, Governor of the State of Mississippi, in answer to a letter from him enclosing the Constitution of the State. Soon after I came from the Office, a Frenchman came to me in great distress. Said he belonged to the Island of Martinique, where he has a wife and three children. He was going there from Carthagena as supercargo of a vessel under danish colours—was taken by an insurgent privateer from Margenta, stripp’d of every thing, even his clothes and landed in utter destitution at Norfolk. The french Consul there could not relieve him because he was not in the king’s service. He travelled here to ask Justice and assistance from the President or the french Minister, neither of whom being here he had been referred to me. I advised him to proceed and reach Philadelphia, where the French Consul might find him the means of returning to his home— It was past five O’Clock, when my wife returned from our house, which is preparing for our reception. We dined accordingly late. Chess after dinner with Frye.

4. IV: I waked before three and had afterwards no sleep. This is the inconvenience which I have never been able to avoid, when I have been bent upon a course of early rising. The hour I would now fix upon if possible as invariable, would be from four to five. But more than half the days I wake earlier—at three—at two—and sometimes even before that— The repose of the night is broken, and I suffer an invincible and painful drowsiness all the succeeding day. As Evening draws on I dose, and fall asleep in Company, and only find relief by a longer Night, and sleeping in the morning later than my intended hour— This morning I drafted a short Letter to the President, and an introductory notice to precede the publication of the De Neuville Documents. Had a visit from Captain Tingey, and from the starving Italian Sculptor Cardelli, who brought Letters of Recommendation from Mr Trumbull at New-York. He draws in Crayons also, and asked my leave to take a portrait of my wife, to give him something to do. He wants to take a Bust of the President, and to be employed on the works at the Capitol. I called on Mr Crawford, the Secretary of the Treasury, and consulted with him concerning the four commercial Articles proposed by Lord Castlereagh: he thinks that nothing can be done with them. Mr George Graham the acting Secretary at War, settled my Account for the Books purchased for G. Boyd, on Account of the War Department, and I received from the Treasurer T. T. Tucker an order for the payment of the Money. Mr John Graham called on me— He says the President’s views with regard to the contemplated Mission to South-America have partly changed— It was again near five when my wife came from our house, home to dinner. Mrs Hellen and Mary came in after dinner. Walked with them and my wife to W. S. Smith’s, whose wife is ill. we met there Boyd and his wife. He shewed me a Letter that he received this morning from Mr Pope who is in political trouble. D. P. Cook was with us there and afterwards at Frye’s. He goes to-morrow for Kentucky.

5. V: The Ladies went this morning to St. John’s Church; and after their return I went with my wife and paid visits to Commodore and Mrs Rogers, Mr and Mrs Pleasonton, Coll. and Mrs Freeman, Mrs Lear and her Son in Law. Commodore and Mrs Decatur, and Mr and Mrs Middleton at Georgetown; from whence I walked home. After dinner I walked with my wife and Mr and Mrs Frye, first to a house of Captain Davidson’s which he has for sale and has offered to me; and afterwards to the house which we are going to occupy— My wife was not pleased with Davidson’s house. I received by the Mail Letters from J. B. Prevost and Captain Biddle of the Ontario Sloop of War, the departure of which is still delayed.

6. VI: By day-light, in consequence of the fatiguing exercise of yesterday. It abridged my writing before breakfast by two full hours. Cardelli the Sculptor came again to the Office. I directed him to call to-morrow at eleven at Mr Frye’s, to take the portrait of my wife— Judge Cranch called to see me, but sat with me only a few minutes. I called upon Mr Crawford the Secretary of the Treasury, about the Instructions to be given to Captain Biddle; but afterwards I received a Letter from J. B. Prevost mentioning that Biddle had given him notice that he was ready for Sea, and that he Prevost should embark on Sunday Morning. Crawford told me he was writing to the President upon a very unpleasant subject, implicating the character of Van Zandt a Clerk, and even of
Josiah Meigs, Commissioner of the Land Office. We spoke of the four Articles proposed by Lord Castlereagh to be added to the Commercial Convention. We agreed that nothing can be made of them. He also mentioned the complaint of Mr Bagot, at our duties upon rolled (British) being heavier than upon hammered (Swedish) iron. He said he thought there was reason in the complaint, and that the extra duties levied upon rolled iron, since the Convention ought to be paid back. Mr Rush came and gave me the minute I had requested of all the points upon which he wished for Instructions. He is going to-morrow to Annapolis and Philadelphia. He wishes on the Voyage in the Franklin, to provide his own Stores— W. Lee brought me a Letter to him from the two L’Allemand’s disclaiming all intention of engaging in any enterprize contrary to the Laws of the United States— After dinner I attempted a walk with my wife to Mr Boyd’s; but in the dusk we both stepped into a mud-puddle opposite to Mrs Hellen’s house, and were obliged to return home— I wrote a couple of short Letters.

7. IV: Finished the first draft of Instructions for Rush. Letter to the President. Mr A. R. Levering of Baltimore came to the Office, to solicit the appointment of marshal for the district of Maryland, vacant by the death of Mr Reitter the day before yesterday— There was a Letter from Commodore Barney, yesterday received also asking for the Office. Excepting the visit of Mr Levering I had the morning at the Office uninterrupted. I read the Letters from Mr Silsbee of Salem, Mr William Irving of New-York, and Genl Smith of Baltimore in answer to questions addressed to them by Mr Rush for their opinions on the four proposed commercial Articles of Lord Castlereagh. And I likewise read Mr Jefferson’s Report upon Weights and Measures made to the House of Representatives in January 1791— This is a subject which weighs much upon my mind. When I came home I found the Ladies had dined, and they immediately went up to our house. Mr Frye and I dined together without them— And we afterwards took a two Miles walk. Mr Tyler came and took away his fac-simile of the Declaration of Independence. I wrote two or three short Letters. My wife received one from her Sister, Mrs Pope, full of politics and personalities.

8. IV:15.Mr Nourse the Register of the Treasury called at the Office, and introduced Josiah Meigs the Commissioner of the Land Office. Mr Baker, ex-Consul at Tarragona in Spain came with an account to be allowed. I received a Letter from the President which I answered. Collected together the papers received concerning weights and measures, but was interrupted by the multitude of Letters received, and had scarcely the time necessary for reading them— Mr Frye had company to dinner—Messrs: Robert and Daniel Brent, Mr Harrison the Auditor of the Treasury, and Coll. Constant Freeman— Harrison also passed the Evening here. I could of course write nothing, and read little and to no purpose.

9. III:45. Finished the first draft of instructions to Mr Rush, and of a Circular Letter to the Consuls of the United States in the British Dominions. At the Office Mr Bagot came to tell me he should go to-morrow, for his visit to Mr Madison in Virginia— Mr G. A. Hughes came to recommend himself for the appointment of Marshal for the District of Maryland. Mr Pleasonton to introduce Mr Cox formerly Consul at Tunis, and now a candidate for the Consulate General at Algiers. He says that Shaler is very desirous of coming home— And Mr Tayloe came to pay a visit of civility. I wrote to the President, but made very little progress in my researches upon weights and measures— After dinner the Ladies went to Georgetown, and I walked to Mr Boyd’s where I spent a couple of hours. Found Mrs Hellen there, and accompanied her home. I had risen so early that I was unfit for application in the Evening and took to my bed soon after eight O’Clock.

10. VI: Began this morning the first draft of a Report upon weights and measures. Called at the Bank, and took an order on the U. S. Branch Bank at New York in favour of H. Hughes to pay for the freight of my furniture from New-York to this place. Tyler the Calligrapher called at the Office and we compared his copy of the Declaration of Independence with the fac-similes of the signatures, with the original. I found the copy very good, but the signatures not so exactly imitated, as Mr Rush’s certificate upon Tyler’s copy attests. Mr Bailey also a Candidate for the Marshal’s Office in Maryland was at the Office. Pleasonton brought me a Statement of my vouched and unvouched charges in my Accounts— I was much busied with enquiries about weights and measures. Walked after dinner with Frye in Georgetown. W. S. Smith and his wife spent the Evening here. I read De Pradt’s pamphlet on the first restoration of the Bourbons, which my father has sent me to be returned to Mr Jefferson.

11. III:15. The weights and measures absorb most of my time. Elias B. Caldwell paid me a visit at the Office, and had some Conversation with me concerning the Society formed for sending a Colony of free Blacks and people of Colour. It was a Mr Mills who gave me the pamphlet upon the subject in the Steam-Boat, between New-Haven and New-York— The intentions of the Society are benevolent, but I believe their project to be impracticable and dangerous— I received a Letter from the President, in forming me that he has determined to return here as soon as his Carriage which he has
sent for to this place, arrives. I have found it necessary to keep a minute from day to day of all the Letters received Mr Brent says it was the constant practice of Mr Jefferson when he was in the department. This day there were fourteen received, with sundry Packets. After dinner I walked alone as far as the Theatre; and on returning to Frye’s found Mr Boyd, and Mrs Hellen there. Boyd invited us all to his house to supper. Mr and Mrs Frye could not go, she having been all day quite unwell. The rest of us called at W. S. Smith’s; where we found Mrs Boyd; who with Mr and Mrs. Smith went with us, and we all supped at Boyd’s— It was past eleven when we came home.

12. V: I cannot regulate my rising hours— I was again awake before four, and after an hour of vain endeavour to sleep rose at five. I went with Mr Frye to St. John’s Church, and heard Mr Hawley the Minister, read the Morning prayer for the 19th. Sunday after Trinity, with the Litany, but no part of the Communion Service— He announced the Communion for next Sunday, and read the same exhortation to attend it, that I had heard four weeks ago from Bishop Hobart at New-York. He preached also from Philippians III:18. For many walk, of whom I have told you often, and now tell you, even weeping, that they are the enemies of the Cross of Christ— The Sermon was well written, and not ill-delivered; but near three quarters of an hour long; and of a sharp and rigorous doctrine. Coming out of Church I met Mr Gadsden who has just arrived, and proceeding on his return to Charleston. Afterwards Mr Hughes, Mr Bagot’s Secretary— Then Mr Magner, and Commodore Decatur, and finally Mrs Catherine Brown and her daughter— The mother is an acquaintance of mine, of more than thirty years standing, and resided at Newbury-Port when I was there as a student at Law. She now is a widow and keeps a school in Georgetown— Mrs Frye was very unwell and did not dine with us. We dined early, and immediately after dinner came to the house which I have hired for a year, of Mr Daniel Brent. It is in 4 1/2 Street about half a mile from the Capitol and a mile from the President’s House. Here if it please God, we are settled for one year. The removal occasioned some little interruption of my writing, but not much. We made a short Evening.

13. V: Began the day by writing a Letter to Mr Jefferson. Mr Richard Bland Lee, made a visit to the Office, and a man named Allen, came with a proposal of subscription for Neal’s history of the Puritans. After returning from the Office I walked over the Canal of the Tiber, to a house and Estate on the Banks of the Potowmac and near the Bridge, sold a few days since at Auction, and which I have had some thoughts of taking— We dined between five and six O’Clock, and the Evening was absorbed as many others must be in unpacking books and papers.

14. IV:30. The morning was stormy, and I consumed so much of it in unpacking, that I lost the greater part of it for writing; and it was noon before I went to the Office— I found some of the vouchers wanted by Mr Pleasonton for the settlement of my accounts— Took them with me to him at the Treasury— There are yet some others missing. A Man named Isaacs came to complain that Dr Thornton refused him a patent to which he was entitled— Mr M’Cormick the Church Clergyman paid me a visit at the house. We employed the Evening in arranging all the Letter that I received in England, in alphabetical order. It will take us eight or ten evenings to complete the work.

15. IV:45. Began a Letter to A. H. Everett. Sent to Mr Pleasonton a Trunk full of Consular Accounts and vouchers; and I took to him the vouchers of my own Accounts which I had not found until yesterday— They were the minutes of Meyer and Brüxners draughts upon the Willink’s and Van Staphorst’s for me, while I was in Russia— I received a Letter and two Packets from the President; one containing Remarks of Mr Yard of Philadelphia, upon the Commercial Convention with Great-Britain of 3. July 1815. and upon the four additional Articles proposed by Lord Castlereagh; and the other, the Letters of Mr Holmes, Commissioner under the 4th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent, and of J. T. Austin the Agent. The President directed me to write to Mr Holmes, and promise him a further communication after his return here. I wrote accordingly, but before the Letter was despatched I received one from J. T. Austin, mentioning that the difficulties were all removed, the Commissioners having agreed upon their Report which they are to declare at a meeting on the 24th. of November at New-York— My Letter to Holmes was therefore not sent. I was again employed
with my wife all the Evening in arranging alphabetically the files of Letters which I received while last in England. I shall make the attempt of bringing my books and Papers into some order.

16. VI:15. By broad daylight. Mead the Carpenter called here this Morning, about the place which he bought last week at Auction, and which I have had some thoughts of purchasing. He will call again with the plans of the place to-morrow— I barely finished my Letter to Everett, and wasted part of the Morning— At the Office I spent the time chiefly in reading over the last despatches from W. Eustis— I wrote a Letter to him acknowledging the receipt of them, and requested Mr Brent to have a similar Letter to each of the other Ministers abroad from whom despatches have been received since I came into the Office— There was a despatch from D. Sheldon, N. 41 received, and a private Letter N. 14, from J. A. Smith— Mr and Mrs Frye dined with us, and with Mr and Mrs Boyd, and Mrs. Hellen passed the Evening here— Mr Brent’s black boy Ben came this Morning. Mrs Adams had a visit from Mr and Mrs Crawford.

17. IV:15. Though I rose thus early my time to the hour of breakfast was not so profitably employed as it might have been. I receive at the Office a multitude of Newspapers from every part of the United States which are destroyed or taken for waste paper, by the Messengers— All the Papers from abroad are used in the same manner. I have directed that files of the Morning Chronicle, Courier and Times, should henceforth be kept for the use of the Office: and as in casting my eye over the papers that are brought with the daily Mails, I have thought it might be useful to take home with me, and keep files of the National Intelligencer and Boston Patriot, and a Miscellaneous file, of such papers as contain any thing to which I may wish hereafter to refer— To make the last file however of any value, I must mark, and number the Article in each paper, for which it is kept, and keep an index of corresponding numbers— I made this morning the necessary arrangements for this— Mead the Carpenter was here again with the plans of the place he bought last week; but the lands around it are so different from what I had expected, being all to the Northward, instead of going to the river that I gave up the idea of taking it. I returned however before three from the Office and walked with my wife over to the house, which we examined and which is in a condition requiring great repairs— We met Mead there; but the ground he had bought was not staked out so that he could know precisely what it was. From the plan however it was evidently North of the House, and the House itself, built many years before the Cession of the District to the United States stands almost entirely upon one of the Streets according to the plan of the City; is liable to be taken down, whenever the street shall be laid out; and the land upon which it stands will not even be included in the conveyance— The spot is one of the most beautiful in the City. Mr Purviance, one of the Clerks in the Office returned this day from Baltimore, after an absence of three weeks. I employed this Evening again with my wife in arranging the Letters received in England.

18. V:30. I wrote about half a page of the draft of a Report upon weights and Measures; but I find myself already, insensibly sliding into relaxation and waste of time. I lost much of the morning in assorting Papers— Cardelli brought me the Portrait of my wife that he has taken in Crayons, but as I was not satisfied with the likeness, he requested that she would sit again, which she did— After dinner, I walked with her to Mr Boyd’s where we passed the Evening. W. S. Smith and his wife, and Mrs. Hellen were there. We came home about ten.

19. V: Returned to my occupation upon weights and measures, upon which my progress is excessively slow. Mr Daniel Brent called to tell me that he is going out of town, and will return on Tuesday. I went with my wife, and paid visits to Mr & Mrs Crawford, Mr and Mrs Caldwell, Mr: and Mrs Clay, Mr and Mrs Tayloe, Captain and Mrs Thompson, and General and Mrs Mason, on their island— I saw only Mrs Clay, and Genl Mason. Mr Clay is absent on a visit to Richmond in Virginia. Mrs Mason was unwell, confined to her room where she received Mrs Adams— I walked home— The Mail was brought to my house, and the Evening was employed in reading the Letters and Newspapers which came with it.

20. IV: This is the horse-racing week in the city, in consequence of which our Offices were in part deserted. I sent to Mr. Pleasonton, my public Letter Book and Letters from R. W. Fox explanatory of his accounts. I also called upon him, and enquired if he had finished the examination of my own accounts. He said there were some charges upon which as I am now myself in the Department of State, he must take the directions of the President. W. Lee called at the Office, and told me that the project of the French emigrant Officers for an invasion of Mexico, were all broken up and abandoned. When I came home from the Office, I found Mrs W. S. Smith with my wife. She dined with us, and in the Evening we walked home with her— Joseph Dougherty a man who lived sometime with my father, and with Mr Jefferson, the whole time of his presidency, came to recommend himself for an office of copying Clerk in any of the public Offices. He had with him a strong recommendation from Mr Jefferson.

21. V: On going this morning to the Office, I was informed that the President had returned last Evening to the City. I came home therefore at Noon with a view to go with my wife and pay visits to Mrs Monroe, and her daughter Mrs. Hay, who is with her; but my wife was gone out, and after waiting till three O’Clock for her return, I sat out to go to the President’s alone— I met her in the avenue, coming home, but she was fatigued with her walk, and could not turn back. I found the President at his house, and had an hours Conversation with him— Mr Crawford came in while I was there, and I left him with the President— It was past five when I got home to dinner. John Spear Smith called on me at the Office this Morning, and spent the Evening with us. All the world at the races.

22. IV: I attended the President this Morning with all the Papers that had been prepared to be submitted to him and was with him nearly three hours, receiving his directions upon the various objects to which they relate. I then returned to the Office, and immediately went with my wife and visited Mrs Monroe, and Mrs Hay, but we were not received. I was then at the Office till four— We had scarcely risen from dinner, when Mr Cox, the candidate for the Consulate General at Algiers came in and passed the Evening with us.

23. V:30. In the course of my enquiries on the subject of weights and measures, I find the necessity of making some calculations upon which I began this Morning, and they occupied me so much that they suspended the progress of my draft for a report. Going to the Office I met Mr Rush, who turned back with me, and with whom I had a long conversation upon the prospects of his Mission, in relation to his personal and domestic concerns— I received a Note from Mr Bagot requesting me to appoint a time when I could receive him; Mr Brent answered it and I fixed one O’Clock to-morrow to see him. I received a Letter from Mr Frederic Greuhm at Philadelphia, announcing his arrival with a Commission from the King of Prussia, as Minister Resident and Consul General; and enclosing a copy of his credential Letter which is addressed to the Congress of the United States, in French— I went to the President’s and took his directions, which were to invite Mr Greuhm to come immediately to Washington— I asked if the Address to Congress of the Credentials should be noticed in writing or informally, in conversation— He said informally only, and in Conversation— I mentioned to him some other objects. But he was engaged with the acting Secretary at War G. Graham, and General Mason, so that I had only a few minutes of time and could enter into no details. I returned to the Office, and wrote the note to Greuhm, and despatched it by the day’s Mail. N. Frye, G. Boyd and W. S. Smith and their wives, R. Rush, D. Brent, and J. Spear Smith dined with us. My wife went and passed the Evening at Boyd’s, where I went to come home with her. The weather is fine and at summer warmth.

24. V:15. Morning absorbed in arithmetical calculations and Logarithms— Not a line upon weights and measures. It was noon before I went to the Office. I had a visit from R. J. Meigs the Postmaster, General, and from Allan Pollock, an Englishman, long settled at Boston, who has invented Patent Scales, and came to offer his services to supply the United States with standard weights and Measures. He says the Treasurer of the State of Massachusetts employs him to keep the Custody of the Standard weights and measures of the State— Mr Pleasonton came with my accounts, many charges of which he questions— Mr Bagot came at one; and was engaged with me upwards of an hour, conferring upon various subjects— I had Letters from C. Hughes junr.J. M. Forbes, and many others. Began the Register of Letters received, for which the Book was not ready until this day. It was past three before I could call at the President’s and I was with him upwards of an hour. I asked him at what time it would best suit his convenience that I should call upon him daily. He said he had given a general order to receive me at all times; but in a few days he would fix upon some regular hour to see me, as it would be necessary for him to take some part of the day for exercise— He desired me to come to his house to-morrow Morning at eleven to meet Mr Crawford and Mr Rush (as he had been in the Department of State, and a Member of the Government) for a consultation upon various points, and particularly with regard to South-America— He should put the question whether we should now acknowledge the Government of Buenos-Ayres.?— I took his directions upon various subjects and left
left him at half past four. Mr and Mrs Boyd were here after dinner, and Mr Cox paid us another visit but was not received. My wife was all day quite unwell. I returned again for about an hour to the logarithms.

25. IV: Much of the Morning was again occupied with Logarithms— At eleven O’Clock I went to the Office, and immediately afterwards to the President’s where there was a Cabinet Meeting— Mr Crawford, Mr Rush, and the acting Secretary at War, G. Graham were there— The President proposed a series of questions relating chiefly to Spain and the South American Insurgents— They were discussed until half past three O’Clock— No decision was taken upon any of the questions, but the President adjourned the meeting to next Tuesday— I dined with my wife at G. Boyd’s. The former Serjeant at Arms of the House of Representatives, Wheaton came in after dinner— I walked home, and soon after my wife came in and told me that W. S. Smith was taken upon a process of Bail from the State of New-York for 500 dollars. He is to go to-morrow Morning and his wife is at Boyd’s— Cardelli brought home a second time my wife’s portrait; not much improved.

26. VI:30. After Sunrise; and all the leisure of the day was absorbed in writing to my brother. Cardelli was here immediately after breakfast. He saw the President yesterday but he does not incline to have his bust taken. MrC. D. Coxe also came and stated over again his pretensions to the Consulate of Algiers. He is anxious for an immediate decision; and called here the Evening before last and twice yesterday at the Office to see me. With my wife I paid visits to Mr and Mrs Cutts, Mr and Mrs Carr— Commodore Porter and his Lady, Mr and Mrs. T. Petre at Georgetown, and Mrs Bagot— We were received only at Carr’s and Petre’s— Mrs Petre, presented to us her daughters Columbia and Britannia Wellington. I walked home— Mr T. Law and his two Sons had paid me a visit yesterday Morning, and Messrs:R. and D. Brent this Morning.

27. V:30.Mr John Bailey whom I had appointed as one of the Clerks in the Department, arrived here last Evening and presented himself at my house this Morning. He afterwards came to the Office, and had the Oaths administered to him by Mr Robert Brent. Mr Cutts brought a letter to him, of recommendation for some person to Office. General Mason came to say that a Mr Lagueire a Minister appointed by the Government of Buenos Ayres wished me to appoint a time when I would see him— As this is a Government not yet recognized, I told General Mason that I would take the President’s directions, and give him an answer. Mr Bagot came and I conversed with him upon various topics— Captain Davidson came, and spoke of a house in F. Street which I have agreed to purchase of him. But he has mislaid the deeds— It was four O’Clock when I went to the President’s with the papers to be submitted to him, and past five when I left him and came home. I employed the Evening with my wife in partly preparing an Index to the Letters received in England— I was this Morning at the Comptroller, Mr Anderson’s Office; at the 5th: Auditor Mr Pleasonton’s, and at the Bank— Mr Law met me, and promised to send me a pamphlet written by him on the national currency which he accordingly sent me this Evening.

28. V:Commodore Barney called upon me on Sunday Morning. He was a candidate for the Office of Marshal for the District of Maryland, but now says he could not accept that appointment. He wishes for that of Naval Officer; but there is a remonstrance against his appointment by some of the Inhabitants of Baltimore. He says that he is nevertheless popular at Baltimore, but that he has been these fifteen years at War with Genl. S. Smith, and the remonstrance comes only from Smith’s partizans. The President offered Barney the place of Agent to the Government of Petion in Saint Domingo or Hayti, but he says he cannot go there because there is not a white face there with whom he or his wife could associate— This morning a Mr Strong came to the Office with papers relating to a claim that he has against the Government of Petion, and offered himself to go there if Barney should finally decline— At twelve O’Clock, I attended the Cabinet Meeting at the President’s. It continued till near four, and a further meeting was fixed for the day after to-morrow, at eleven. In the meantime I am to see the Agent from the Buenos Ayres Government to-morrow, and to hear and report at the next Meeting what he has to say. I returned to the Office, and despatched one or two Letters— In the Evening I proceeded in making the Index, with my wife. She had spent the morning at Mrs Boyd’s— W. S. Smith went off on Sunday Morning, but they do not know for what he was taken, or how a Sheriff’s Officer from New-York, could serve a process here. I called again this Morning upon Pleasonton, with some of the papers for which he had asked and which I had found. He still objects to some of the items of my account, and proposed to me to see and converse with the comptroller upon them. The weather became cold this Evening—

29. V: Having resumed this Morning the draft of a Report upon weights and measures, I was detained until a late hour before I could go to the Office; and just as I was going out received a visit from Major Mercer. Before reaching the Office I met Mr T. W. Norman who had come from Baltimore to renew his application for the Consulate of Amsterdam. Mr Bourne had held that Office about 25 years, and a great part of the time had been instant in solicitations for a salary or some compensation; never could he obtain it, until at the last Session of Congress when there was an appropriation for him as agent for Seamen at the Hague— But before he was informed of it he died. This Salary of 2000 dollars a year, has stimulated about ten times the number of applications for the Consulate of Amsterdam, that there would have been without it. Mr John Martin Baker, and Mr Cathcart are also applicants for it— both with families, and both in great want; Baker came again to the Office this morning to press his claims. I told both him and Mr Norman that probably the Salary would not be allowed; but Norman is willing to take it without the Salary— At twelve O’Clock, General Mason came with Don Manuel Hermenegildo Aguirre the person sent as an Agent from the Government of Buenos Ayres. He gave me a Letter to the President, containing the Declaration of Independence of Buenos Ayres, with an exposition of the motives of that act, written by himself; and two Commissions to himself; enclosed in a sealed packet addressed to me. One Commission was from the United Provinces of South-America (Buenos Ayres) signed by the Supreme Director Puyerredon, styling Aguirre Commissary General of War, and constituting him Agent of the Government near that of the United States. The other was from the Government of Chili signed by the Director O’Higgins and was merely an authority for purchasing warlike Stores— I had a Conversation with him of more than an hour, and after he left me took to the President the Letter for him, together with many other papers. The President had sent me this Morning the Draft of Instructions for Mr Rush with a memorandum for alterations on three points. On conversing with him, and recurring to the Commercial Convention of 3. July 1815. he directed me to leave the draft, on that point, as it stands, without alteration— On the second, the allowance of necessary expence for Office Rent, he reserved the decision, but inclined to leave it as it stands— The other alteration that he desired was inconsiderable— I proposed to him to add a standing instruction against accepting the bauble presents that the European Sovereigns offer to Ministers accredited to them, when they take leave, or upon the conclusion of Treaties, to which he readily assented. It was five O’Clock when I got home. G. Boyd was with us in the Evening. I received a Letter from John Vaughan of Philadelphia, with the Indentures of two German Redemptioners, a boy, and a woman; and the account of charges for engaging them. They are shipped in a vessel for Georgetown.

30. V: Wrote to Mr Vaughan, and sent him a draft on U. S. Bank at Philadelphia— Made the alterations and additions to the draft of Instructions for Mr Rush— Called again upon Pleasonton, on the subject of the settlement of my accounts. He agreed to call upon the Comptroller with me to-morrow. The Cabinet meeting at the President’s was fixed for twelve O’Clock; but it was half past twelve before I got to the Office, and the President sent a messenger to say he was waiting for me. I attended immediately and the Meeting sat till near four— The President had presented several written questions for consideration relating to South-American Affairs, to our relations with Spain, and to a piratical assemblage at Amelia Island, and at Galveztown. This day Mr Graham who is Chief Clerk in the War Department, and acting Secretary, observed that the six Months allowed by Law, for substitutes to act instead of Heads of Departments, had expired in his case, and he had scruples as to his right of assisting any longer at the Meetings. Mr Rush observed that he was under a similar embarrassment, considering his Office of Attorney General as vacated by his new Appointment of Minister to Great-Britain. The President said he had offered the Office of Secretary of War to Mr Calhoun of South Carolina, and was daily expecting his answer— Mr Crowninshield the Secretary of the Navy was on his way to the City, and expected here in a few days,
and he, the President had written this morning to Mr Wirt of Richmond Virginia, offering him the Office of Attorney General, but it was very doubtful whether he would accept it. The President said that he should have been very desirous of having a Western Gentleman in the Cabinet; but he could not see his way clear— He had taken great pains to inform himself, but he could not learn that there was any one lawyer in the Western Country, suitably qualified for the Office. He had particularly enquired of Judge Todd, who had assured him there was no such suitably qualified person— This he said was perfectly confidential— Graham said that he had enquired this Morning of Mr Clay; who had told him, also confidentially, the same thing—that there was no lawyer in that Country, fit for the Office of Attorney General— The questions were again discussed, and as it appeared to me that all the gentlemen were backward in giving their opinions, upon almost every one of them I finally gave mine explicitly that the marauding parties at Amelia-Island and Galveztown ought to be broken up immediately. This was at once determined upon, and it was considered as a decisive Reason, for despatching the Commissioners, and the frigate Congress to Buenos Ayres. I also suggested the expediency of waiting for the next despatch from Mr Erving, before assuming any new attitude with Spain, which, was agreed to; and I also explicitly avowed my opinion that it is not now expedient for the President to acknowledge the Government of Buenos Ayres— But the President postponed his determination upon this— The meeting broke up at four— After I came home Mr Anderson, the Comptroller, and his second Son came, and sat with me till near seven. My wife dined and spent the Evening at her sister’s Mrs Boyd’s.

31. V: I had promised to call with Mr Pleasonton at the Comptroller, Mr Anderson’s at half past ten O’Clock, but it was near twelve when I got to Pleasonton’s, and I found with him a Mr Taylor who has been agent of the United States to Petion’s Government in St. Domingo, and who wants to go there again or to have some equivalent appointment. He struck his flag and came away on account of the seizure and confiscation of Strong’s Schooner Mary and her Cargo. Strong made a long Statement of the case to which he made Oath before Robert Brent, for the justification of his character. He brought it to me, and has been very importunate for a declaration from me that I am convinced of his integrity. I detected this Morning a gross misrepresentation in this statement, and on telling Strong of it, he made a lame and ineffectual attempt to explain it. I called at Mr Andersons with Pleasonton and gave him some explanation of my Accounts. But I must give it to him in writing— Taylor and Strong kept me at the Office till past four. There was a storm of Rain with little intermission the whole day— I was engaged all the Evening in reading over the letters and papers received by the mail— I had appointed this day twelve o’clock to see Mr Aguirra, but forgot the appointment. He left a note for me saying that he was going to Baltimore, and would call upon me on his return. He is going on account of a British vessel which has come to him from Buenos Ayres laden with hydes, and which has been seized at Baltimore, according to the Navigation act, passed at the lest Session of Congress.

Day. Since the twelfth of this Month we have been settled in the house of Daniel Brent, at the Corner of North C Street, and four and a half Street. I rise usually from five to six, having already much relaxed from the industry with which I began. I write Letters, or my Journal, or at the Draft of a Report upon Weights and measures until ten—Breakfast and go to my Office at eleven or twelve— I find there visitors or papers to sign or Letters to frank which employ me till two, when the Mail brings Letters, packets and Newspapers which absorb one or two hours. Then I go to take the Presidents Instructions upon them. I seldom get home to dinner till past five— After dinner, I read or write from seven till nine or ten in the Evening, when I retire to bed— I always walk to and from my Office— The distance is a few yards more than a mile and a quarter—a 22 minutes walk.
